evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary pushback control lapse: active tug instructor failed to stop at TRP. NEC: The required TRP stop/release point was reached but not complied with; Pushback movement continued beyond TRP until blast-fence contact

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary coordination failure: challenge/alert breakdown among ground crew. NEC: Crew held divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent; No timely effective challenge or stop warning occurred despite cues

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary environmental/marking deficiency at TRP. NEC: TRP marking visibility/prominence/placement was inadequate; The marking deficiency plausibly caused or materially enabled the TRP miss

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary mechanical or control-system failure. NEC: A tug or aircraft control/braking malfunction affected stopping; Corroboration exists via tests, diagnostics, or repeat failures

slot_statements.availability: The primary coordination failure involving challenge/alert breakdown among ground crew was present and observable during the early historical timeframe of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: This root cause withstands potential defeaters as the evidence consistently shows no effective challenge or stop warning occurred, and crew assumptions diverged, confirming the coordination failure.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The root cause aligns with key features of the incident, including divergent assumptions held by crew about stop-state or intent, and the absence of timely effective challenge or stop warnings despite available cues.

slot_statements.availability: The primary pushback control lapse was available for observation during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA operation on 12-25, specifically in the early historical timeframe hist_t1_early.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: This procedural deviation is resistant to defeaters as the evidence clearly shows non-compliance with the TRP stop requirement, with no indications of external factors justifying the failure to stop at the TRP.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The lapse fits key features of procedural deviation where the active tug instructor failed to stop at the designated TRP, despite the required TRP stop/release point being reached, resulting in pushback movement continuing beyond TRP until blast-fence contact.

node.statement: The primary coordination failure involving challenge/alert breakdown among ground crew was present and observable during the early historical timeframe of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25.

assumptions: Continued movement beyond TRP without stop implies lack of effective challenge or alert
Interaction between tug instructor and trainee reflects coordination dynamics relevant to communication breakdown
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely challenge or stop warnings before TRP exceedance
If the TRP stop-state was clearly shared and understood by all crew

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H5 shows the tug instructor and trainee had interaction and control changes, with the aircraft passing the TRP without a timely stop, indicating coordination failure and challenge/alert breakdown supporting R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit mention of crew communication content or timing of challenge/alert messages; ambiguity in exact coordination details

node.statement: The root cause aligns with key features of the incident, including divergent assumptions held by crew about stop-state or intent, and the absence of timely effective challenge or stop warnings despite available cues.

assumptions: The absence of explicit mention of stop warnings implies they were not timely or effective.
The cues referenced are the TRP markings and the instructor's and trainee's interactions.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely challenge or stop warnings were given and ignored, or if TRP markings were proven inadequate causing the incident, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows divergent assumptions and lack of effective challenge or stop warnings despite cues, supporting R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN over R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in the extent of communication effectiveness and possible environmental factors not fully detailed in evidence.

node.statement: The primary pushback control lapse was available for observation during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA operation on 12-25, specifically in the early historical timeframe hist_t1_early.

assumptions: The TRP was visible and recognizable to the tug instructor during the pushback.
No mechanical control failures prevented stopping at the TRP.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was not visible or marked adequately to the crew, or if mechanical control failures were documented, this would change the conclusion.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 and H3 show the tug instructor was actively controlling the pushback and attentive, while H4 confirms the aircraft passed the TRP and collided with the blast fence, supporting the availability of the primary pushback control lapse during the operation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence about TRP visibility or mechanical faults; assumption that instructor had opportunity to observe TRP.

node.statement: The lapse fits key features of procedural deviation where the active tug instructor failed to stop at the designated TRP, despite the required TRP stop/release point being reached, resulting in pushback movement continuing beyond TRP until blast-fence contact.

defeaters: If evidence showed verified braking or control faults causing the pushback to continue beyond TRP, this would favor R4 and change the conclusion.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly states the aircraft reached the TRP but continued moving beyond it until hitting the blast fence, supporting the procedural deviation claim (R1) over mechanical failure (R4).
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: This root cause withstands potential defeaters as the evidence consistently shows no effective challenge or stop warning occurred, and crew assumptions diverged, confirming the coordination failure.

assumptions: Crew assumptions about stop-state or intent diverged as inferred from the trainee stopping and instructor taking over without clear shared understanding.
No mechanical fault evidence was found or reported in the provided history.
defeaters: If evidence showed fault codes, repeated malfunctions, or mechanical tests indicating hardware failure, this would favor R4 and challenge R2.
If clear, timely effective stop warnings or challenges had been issued and followed, this would weaken the coordination failure claim.

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

The instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H2-H5) shows no effective stop challenge or warning occurred despite cues, and crew actions indicate divergent assumptions, supporting coordination failure (R2) over mechanical failure (R4).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct mechanical fault evidence is presented; assumptions about crew intent and communication are inferred from actions.

slot_statements.availability: The primary mechanical or control-system failure was present and detectable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as evidenced by historical data from hist_t1_early.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The conclusion of a primary mechanical or control-system failure is resistant to defeaters, given the corroboration through tests, diagnostics, or repeat failures, minimizing alternative explanations in the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The failure aligns with key features of tug or aircraft control/braking malfunctions that affect stopping, supported by corroborative tests, diagnostics, or repeat failures specific to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 event.

node.statement: The failure aligns with key features of tug or aircraft control/braking malfunctions that affect stopping, supported by corroborative tests, diagnostics, or repeat failures specific to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 event.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

slot_statements.availability: The primary environmental or marking deficiency at TRP was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t1_early timeframe.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

No contradictory evidence about marking adequacy is present.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

node.statement: No credible evidence or alternative explanations sufficiently counter the claim that the TRP marking deficiency plausibly caused or materially enabled the TRP miss in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t1_early context.

No mechanical control failure or procedural deviation was the primary cause based on current evidence.
defeaters: If evidence showed the crew recognized and expected the TRP stop but failed due to procedural deviation or communication breakdown, this would weaken the marking deficiency claim.

If evidence showed procedural errors or communication breakdowns fully explained the incident

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft continued moving beyond the TRP with engine at idle and collided with the blast barrier, indicating a mechanical/control failure rather than procedural deviation, supporting defeater resistance for R4.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity
